Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 02:46AM mrsgray317 wrote: Hi Scared, I am 9 weeks out of a prophy skin and nipple sparing BMX.  I had TRAM flap reconstruction.  I had ADH with a very strong family history that now spans three generations.  There are no postive BRCA results in our family, so those tests are not the be all and end all of heredity.  My BS was confident that I was a candidate for prophy surgery.  Both she and one of the patholigists I work with were certain that I would have BC eventually.  I decided that watching and waiting (after already doing so for 15 years) was no longer enough.  I have also had a total of 4 stereotactic biopsies. The TRAM portion of the program has not been easy.  I had 4 surgeries in 5 weeks- one to ligate the vessels that would feed the flap, the big surgery, one to clean out an infection in my breast and the last for a small skin graft on each breast.  I do have a scar that runs from hip to hip, but I got a tummy tuck for my efforts.  My new breasts don't look a whole lot different than my old ones (smaller, by choice).  I am very happy that I had this done.  I now have a 1% chance of developing BC- down from >50% (on paper, probably more like 80% in reality).  I do not have to take tamox-yeah! It sounds like you are not completely at ease with what your doc is saying-get another opinion and another until you feel like what you are hearing makes sense to you. All the Best, Patti
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a nipple-sparing skin sparing mastectomy? ScaredInSnoqualmie momoschki

Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed Yet But Radiologist Not Optimistic Kasi redroks2

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 01:10AM mrsgray317 wrote: Greetings, I am new here too.  I am 49 and have a very strong family history of breast cancer.  My mom has had it in each breast (11 years between diagnoses), her sister, my cousin, many of my mom's cousins and aunts.  Fortunately, there has only been one case that was fatal and that was about 40 years ago.  I went for my annual mammo two weeks ago on a Thursday.  I have already had three stereotactic biopsies for what turned out to be cysts.  My last three mammos have been normal.  I went merrily on my way after the test and didn't think about it again.  On Monday am, my nurse practitioner calls me at work to ask if I have heard anything about my mammo.  When I say no, she asks me to come up to her office right then.  I am a medical technologist in the lab of the same facility.  When I went to see her, she said it wasn't good.  I have a new cluster of microcalcs that were suggestive of DCIS.  I had a magnification mammo the next day and the radiologist cam out to tell me he thought I needed a biopsy.  I got a copy of the report and it was Bi-Rads 4, and the wording was much the same as what was read to me from the first mammo.  Two different radiologists read my films and agreed.  I chose to be seen at a cancer center in a teaching hospital becasue of my family history (and had my previous biopsies there too).  My films went on CD and were read by a radiologist there, who said that I could have another mammo in 6 months.  Uh, no.  I asked for a biopsy based on what my hometown docs had said and on my familt history.  I will have a steriotactic biopsy Monday am.  I am not really scared because I have seen so many of my relatives go through this and survive as well as thrive.  I just feel concerned that there is such disparity between the rads.  I know the only way to know for sure is biopsy and I can't believe that waiting 6 months was even suggested given my family history.  The rad who is doing the steriotactic will be the 4th one on my case so it will be interesting to hear what she has to say.  Anyone else experience this?  Thanks to all...Patti
